case_vignette: a 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of his “weird” behavior. the parents report that their son tortured their cat to death two weeks ago. over the past year, he has been accused of stealing a car and setting a fire at his school. he has no history of serious illness. he attends a local high school, and his performance at school is very poor compared to his classmates. he often loses his temper and argues with his teachers. he has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 2 years. he does not drink alcohol. his mother has a 10-year history of schizophrenia controlled with medication. on mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time. the pupils are equal and reactive to light. his speech is normal in rate and rhythm, and his thought process is organized. short- and long-term memory are intact. attention and concentration are poor.
question: which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I often lose my temper and argue with my teachers, and I've been having trouble paying attention and concentrating.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I have been experiencing these symptoms for about a year.
Do you feel restless or have you been engaging in activities impulsively?
I don't feel particularly restless, but I have been accused of engaging in impulsive activities like stealing a car and setting a fire at my school.
Have you been diagnosed with any psychiatric or neurological conditions in the past?
No, I have no history of serious illness.
Have these symptoms and behaviors caused significant issues in school, at home, or with relationships?
Yes, my behavior has resulted in poor performance at school and often getting into arguments with my teachers.
Do you use any substances like alcohol, drugs, or medications?
I smoke one pack of cigarettes daily, but I do not drink alcohol.
Have there been any similar behavioral issues or mental health conditions in your family?
Yes, my mother has a 10-year history of schizophrenia which is controlled with medication.
Final Diagnosis: Conduct Disorder

trial_0.singleturn_mcq: Final Diagnosis: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder
trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient reports frequent loss of temper and confrontations with teachers, along with difficulty concentrating and paying attention for approximately one year. The patient does not feel particularly restless but has partaken in impulsive behavior, including car theft and setting a fire at school. The patient confirms there is no history of severe illness. Due to these behaviors, the patient has experienced deteriorating academic performance and frequent arguments with teachers. The patient smokes one pack of cigarettes daily, but does not consume alcohol. The patient's mother has a 10-year history of schizophrenia, which is controlled by medication.
